sentences.sentence: “Early in 1882 my father received a letter from India which was a great shock to him.
He nearly fainted( 晕倒 ) at the breakfast table when he opened it, and from that day he sickened to his death.
What was in the letter we could never discover, but I could see as he held it that it was short and written in a scrawling hand.
He had been ill for some time, but he now became rapidly worse, and towards the end of April we were told that he was beyond all hope( 毫无希望 ), and that he wished to have one last talk with us.
When we entered his room he was supported by pillows and breathing heavily.
He asked us to lock the door and to come upon either side of the bed.
Then, grasping our hands, he made a remarkable statement to us, in a voice which was broken as much by emotion( 情感 ) as by pain.
I shall try and give it to you in his own exact words.
‘I have only one thing,’ he said, ‘which weighs upon my mind at this last moment. It is my treatment of poor Morstan’s orphan( 孤儿 ).
The greed which has been my worst sin( 罪孽 ) has kept from her the treasure, half at least of which should have been hers.
And yet I have not used it myself, so foolish a thing is greed.
See that pearl( 珍珠 ) necklace beside the medicine-bottle. I could not bear even to part with that, although I got it out planning to send it to her.
You, my sons, will give her a fair share of the Agra treasure. But send her nothing—not even the necklace—until I am dead.
After all, men have been as bad as this and have recovered.
I will tell you how Morstan died,’ he continued. ‘He had suffered for years from a weak heart, but he hid it from every one. I alone knew it.
When in India, he and I, through a remarkable chain of circumstances, came into possession of( 占有 ) a considerable treasure.
I brought it over to England, and on the night of Morstan’s arrival he came straight over here to claim his share.
Morstan and I had a difference of opinion as to the division of the treasure, and we argued loudly.
Morstan had sprung out of his chair in anger, when he suddenly pressed his hand to his side, his face turned dark, and he fell backwards, cutting his head against the corner of the treasure-chest.
When I stooped( 弯腰 ) over him I found, to my horror, that he was dead.
“ For a long time I sat half distracted( 心神不定的 ), wondering what I should do.
My first impulse( 一时的念头 ) was to call for help; but I realized that there was every chance that( 极有可能 ) I would be accused of his murder( 被指控犯谋杀罪 ).
His death at the moment of a quarrel, and the big cut in his head, would be black against me.
And any official investigation( 调查 ) would bring out some facts about the treasure which I particularly wanted to keep secret.
He had told me that no one knew where he had gone, and there seemed no reason why anyone ever should know.
I was still thinking over the matter, when, looking up, I saw my servant in the doorway. He came quietly in and bolted( 闩上 ) the door behind him.
‘Do not fear, Sahib,’ he said. ‘No one need know that you have killed him. Let us hide him away, and who is the wiser?’
‘I did not kill him,’ said I.
He shook his head and smiled. ‘I heard it all, Sahib,’ said he,‘I heard you quarrel, and I heard the blow. But my lips are sealed. All are asleep in the house. Let us put him away together.’
That was enough to decide me. If my own servant could not believe my innocence, how could I hope to persuade a jury( 陪审团 )?
My servant and I disposed of( 处理 ) the body that night, and within a few days the London papers were full of the mysterious( 神秘的 ) disappearance of Captain Morstan.
You will see that I can hardly be blamed for his death.
My fault lies in the fact that we concealed( 隐藏 ) not only the body, but also the treasure, and that I have kept Morstan’s share as well as to my own.
I wish you, therefore, to make restitution( 物归原主 ).
Put your ears down to my mouth. The treasure is hidden in—’
At this instant( 在这时 ) a horrible change came over his expression; his eyes stared wildly, his jaw dropped, and he yelled, in a voice which I can never forget, ‘Keep him out! Keep him out!’
We both stared round at the window behind us upon which his gaze( 注视 ) was fixed.
A face was looking in at us out of the darkness.
We could see the whitening of the nose where it was pressed against the glass.
It was a bearded, hairy face, with wild cruel eyes and an expression of concentrated hatred.
My brother and I rushed towards the window, but the man was gone.
When we returned to my father, his head had dropped and his heart had stopped.
We searched the garden that night, but found no sign of the intruder( 闯入者 ), except that just under the window a single footmark was visible( 可见的 ) in the flower bed.
But we soon had another and a more striking proof( 证据 ) that there were secret agencies at work.
The next morning, the window of my father’s room was found open.
His cupboards and boxes had been searched, and upon his chest was fixed a torn piece of paper, with the words ‘The sign of the four’ scrawled across it.
What the phrase meant, or who our secret visitor may have been, we never knew.
As far as we can judge, none of my father’s property had been actually stolen, though everything had been searched through.
My brother and I naturally associated this peculiar( 奇怪的 ) incident with the fear which haunted( 长期困扰 ) my father during his life; but it is still a complete mystery( 谜 ) to us.”
At the short account of her father’s death Miss Morstan had turned deadly white, and for a moment I feared that she was about to faint( 晕倒 ).
She rallied( 恢复 ), however, on drinking a glass of water which I quietly poured out for her.
Sherlock Holmes leaned( 倚靠 ) back in his chair with a far-away expression and half-closed eyes.
As I glanced at him, I thought how on that very same day he had complained( 抱怨 ) bitterly of the boredom of life.
Here was a problem which would test his ability to the utmost( 最大限度 ).
Mr. Thaddeus Sholto looked from one to the other of us with an obvious pride at the effect which his story had produced, and then continued.
